facts.text: Writ Petition No. 118 of 1974 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution in Original Jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No. 118 of 1974. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution. L. Kohli, for the petitioner.

facts.text: L. Kohli appeared as counsel for the petitioner

anchor.surface_text: L. Kohli, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Dilip Sinha and G. S. Chatterjee appeared as counsel for the respondent

anchor.surface_text: Dilip Sinha and G. S. Chatterjee, for the respondent.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by CHANDRACHUD, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by CHANDRACHUD, J.-

facts.text: Petitioner was detained by order dated August 23, 1973 passed by District Magistrate, Howrah under Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was detained by an order dated August 23, 1973 passed by the District Magistrate, Howrah, under the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

facts.text: Detention order recites that petitioner was detained to prevent him from acting in any manner prejudicial to maintenance of public order

anchor.surface_text: The order recites that the petitioner was detained with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Particulars of grounds of detention refer to solitary incident dated March 18, 1973

anchor.surface_text: The particulars of the ground of detention refer to a solitary incident dated March 18, 1973.

facts.text: Petitioner and associates armed with swords, Ballams and Lathis attacked group of Bengalees at Rajnarayan Roy Choudhury Ghat Road, Shibpur, Howrah at about 2 p.m. on March 18, 1973 causing severe injuries

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that at about 2 p.m. on that date, the petitioner and his associates being armed with swords, Ballams and Lathis attacked a group of Bengalees at Rajnarayan Roy Choudhury Ghat Road, Shibpur, Howrah causing severe injuries to them.

facts.text: The conduct led to reign of terror in locality, shops and doors of road side houses closed, people fled in panic, afraid of coming out for fear of assault

anchor.surface_text: It is further stated that this companyduct led to a reign of terror in the locality as a result of which the shops and the doors of the read side houses were closed, people of the locality fled away inpanic and the people were generally afraid of companying out of their houses for fear of being assaulted.

facts.text: Particulars furnished to petitioner state he was detained on ground of acting in manner prejudicial to maintenance of public order

anchor.surface_text: The particulars furnished to the petitioner say that the petitioner was detained on the ground you have been acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Counter-affidavit filed on behalf of State Govt shows no other material taken into account by detaining authority

anchor.surface_text: The companynter-affidavit filed on behalf of the State Govt. shows that numberother material was taken into account by the detaining authority while passing the order of detention.

facts.text: Petitioner expressly apprised of acting prejudicial to public order based on single incident in particulars

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was expressly apprised that he had been acting in a manner prejudical to the maintenance of public order as evidenced by the particulars furnished to him. The particulars refer only to a single incident.

facts.text: State Government approved detention on August 30, 1973 by order approving detention order dated 25-8-73

anchor.surface_text: The second ground of attack on the detention order is that when the State Government approved the detention on August 30, 1973 it passed an order approving a detention order dated 25-8-73.

facts.text: Impugned detention order dated August 23, 1973

anchor.surface_text: As the impugned order of detention is dated August 23, 1973 it is urged that while approving the detention of the petitioner, the State Government had before it some other order of detention.

facts.text: State Govt passed order on November 8, 1973 confirming detention order after Advisory Board opinion, referring to order dated August 23, 1973

anchor.surface_text: This is clear from the order passed by the State Govt. on November 8, 1973 companyfirming the order of detention after obtaining the opinion of the Advisory Board. The order of companyfirmation refers to the order of detention dated August 23, 1973.

facts.text: Approval order and confirmation order both refer to detention order No. 1818-C

anchor.surface_text: It must also be stated that as in the order of companyfirmation so in the order of approval, an express reference is made to the detention order bearing No. 1818-C.

facts.text: Detention order passed against petitioner on August 23, 1973 bears No. 1818-C

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention passed against the petitioner on August 23, 1973 bears that very number which shows hat the reference to an order dated 25-8-73 in the order of approval is a topographical mistake.

facts.text: Reference to detention order dated 25-8-73 in approval order is typographical error

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention passed against the petitioner on August 23, 1973 bears that very number which shows hat the reference to an order dated 25-8-73 in the order of approval is a topographical mistake.

facts.text: Court confirms the order of detention and discharges the rule

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we companyfirm the order of detention and discharge the rule in this petition.

facts.text: Petitioner urged that detaining authority had undisclosed material showing criminal course of conduct over long period

anchor.surface_text: Inferentially it is urged, the detaining authority had material before it showing that the petitioner was indulging in a criminal companyrse of companyduct for a long periOd of time and as such material was number disclosed to the petitioner, he bad numberopportunity to meet it, leading thereby to the companytravention of Article 22 5  of the Constitution.

concepts.unlisted_description: Ground for preventive detention under MISA

issues.text: Whether the use of the phrase 'you have been acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order' in the grounds of detention, when particulars refer only to a single incident, implies that the detaining authority relied on undisclosed material over a long period, contravening Article 22(5) of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: The particulars furnished to the petitioner say that the petitioner was detained on the ground you have been acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order. The argument is that the order is founded on a single incident and therefore, the use of language showing that the culpable companyduct on the part

issues.text: Whether the State Government's approval order referring to a detention order dated 25-8-73, instead of the actual date August 23, 1973, vitiates the detention as it suggests approval of a different order?

anchor.surface_text: The second ground of attack on the detention order is that when the State Government approved the detention on August 30, 1973 it passed an order approving a detention order dated 25-8-73. As the impugned order of detention is dated August 23, 1973 it is urged that while approving the detention of the petitioner, the State Government had before it some other order of detention.

arguments.claim: The use of language 'you have been acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order' based on a single incident implies the detaining authority relied on undisclosed material of a long course of criminal conduct, denying opportunity to meet it and contravening Article 22(5)

anchor.surface_text: The particulars furnished to the petitioner say that the petitioner was detained on the ground you have been acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order. The argument is that the order is founded on a single incident and therefore, the use of language showing that the culpable conduct on the part

arguments.court_reasoning: Detaining authorities must exercise care but no unrealistic dissection; counter-affidavit confirms no other material used; expression unfortunate but does not imply undisclosed material; particulars expressly apprise of single incident only

arguments.claim: No other material was taken into account by the detaining authority while passing the order of detention

anchor.surface_text: The counter-affidavit filed on behalf of the State Govt. shows that no other material was taken into account by the detaining authority while passing the order of detention.

As the impugned order of detention is dated August 23, 1973 it is urged that while approving the detention of the petitioner,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rder of detention is dated August 23, 1973 it is urged that while approving the detention of the petitioner, the State Government had before it some o

arguments.court_reasoning: Approval order contains typographical error as confirmation order dated November 8, 1973 refers to August 23, 1973 order after Advisory Board opinion; both approval and confirmation refer to detention order No. 1818-C matching impugned order

arguments.claim: Detaining authorities ought to exercise greatest care but that does not justify unrealistic dissection of detention orders

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in matters involving the liberty of the subject, the detaining authorities ought to exercise the greatest care in the discharge of their functions. But that does not justify an unrealistic dissection of detention orders.

arguments.claim: Use of expression 'you have been acting' though unfortunate does not support that order founded on undisclosed material

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the use of the expression, you have been acting though unfortunate does not support the submission that the order of detention is founded on undisclosed material.

arguments.claim: Petitioner expressly apprised of acting prejudicial to public order as evidenced by particulars referring only to single incident

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was expressly apprised that he had been acting in a manner prejudical to the maintenance of public order as evidenced by the particulars furnished to him. The particulars refer only to a single incident.

arguments.claim: Reference to order dated 25-8-73 in approval order is typographical mistake as impugned order bears No. 1818-C referred in both approval and confirmation orders and confirmation refers to August 23, 1973

anchor.surface_text: This is clear from the order passed by the State Govt. on November 8, 1973 confirming the order of detention after obtaining the opinion of the Advisory Board. The order of confirmation refers to the order of detention dated August 23, 1973. It must also be stated that as in the order of confirmation so in the order of approval,

holdings.text: the use of the expression, you have been acting though unfortunate does number support the submission that the order of detention is founded on undisclosed material

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the use of the expression, you have been acting though unfortunate does number support the submission that the order of detention is founded on undisclosed material.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Counter-affidavit confirms no other material considered by detaining authority; particulars supplied to petitioner refer only to single incident, expressly apprising him of the ground

holdings.text: The petitioner was expressly apprised that he had been acting in a manner prejudical to the maintenance of public order as evidenced by the particulars furnished to him. The particulars refer only to a single incident.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was expressly apprised that he had been acting in a manner prejudical to the maintenance of public order as evidenced by the particulars furnished to him. The particulars refer only to a single incident.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Particulars of detention grounds disclose only one incident, satisfying requirement under Article 22(5) despite phrasing of general ground

holdings.text: It is true that in matters involving the liberty of the subject, the detaining authorities ought to exercise the greatest care in the discharge of their functions. But that does number justify an unrealistic dissection of detention orders.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in matters involving the liberty of the subject, the detaining authorities ought to exercise the greatest care in the discharge of their functions. But that does number justify an unrealistic dissection of detention orders.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances strict scrutiny in liberty cases against overly pedantic interpretation of detention orders

holdings.text: There is numbersubstance in this companytention. The order of approval companytains but a typographical error.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbersubstance in this companytention. The order of approval companytains but a typographical error. This is clear from the order passed by the State Govt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Typographical error in date does not vitiate as approval and confirmation orders reference correct detention number 1818-C matching impugned order dated August 23, 1973

holdings.text: The order of detention passed against the petitioner on August 23, 1973 bears that very number which shows hat the reference to an order dated 25-8-73 in the order of approval is a topographical mistake.
